classes module

class classes.Seq(header, sequence)[source]

Bases: object

A class to represent a biological sequence from FASTA format.

This class stores the header and sequence data from a FASTA record and provides methods to analyze and manipulate the sequence.

header

The header line from the FASTA record (without the ‘>’ character)

Type:

str

sequence

The biological sequence data with whitespace and newlines removed

Type:

str

__init__(header, sequence)[source]

Initialize a biological sequence.

Parameters:

  • header (str) – FASTA record header line

  • sequence (str) – Biological sequence data

get_alphabet()[source]

Determine the sequence alphabet type based on character composition.

The method checks if the sequence contains primarily nucleotide characters (A, C, G, T, U, N) or protein characters (amino acid codes). Sequences containing characters from both sets or unrecognized characters will be classified as ‘unknown’.

Returns:

Sequence type - one of ‘nucleotide’, ‘protein’, or ‘unknown’

Return type:

str

class classes.FastaReader(filename)[source]

Bases: object

A class for reading and parsing FASTA format files.

This class provides methods to validate FASTA files and read sequences from them sequentially using a generator pattern.

filename

Path to the FASTA file to be read

Type:

str

__init__(filename)[source]

Initialize FASTA reader.

Parameters:

filename (str) – Path to FASTA file

is_valid_fasta()[source]

Check if the file conforms to FASTA format.

The validation checks if the first non-empty line of the file starts with the ‘>’ character, which is required for FASTA format.

Returns:

True if file conforms to FASTA format, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

Note

This is a basic validation that only checks the first line. It doesn’t guarantee the entire file is properly formatted.

read_sequences()[source]

Generator for reading sequences from FASTA file.

This method reads the FASTA file line by line and yields Seq objects for each sequence found in the file. It handles multi-line sequences by concatenating all lines until the next header.

Yields:

Seq – Sequence objects from the FASTA file

Raises:

ValueError – If file doesn’t conform to FASTA format

Example

>>> reader = FastaReader('sequences.fasta')
>>> for seq in reader.read_sequences():
...     print(f"Header: {seq.header}, Length: {len(seq)}")
classes.main()[source]

Main function demonstrating the usage of FastaReader and Seq classes.

This function: 1. Creates a FastaReader instance with a specific file path 2. Validates the FASTA file 3. Reads and displays information about the first 30 sequences 4. Shows sequence headers, lengths, and alphabet types
